post_text: At the Governor’s request DHEC has developed a process to compile and report this data on a bi-weekly basis starting the week of August 30, 2020. Every Tuesday and Friday, DHEC will report the data in two ways – through a cumulative list and a last 30 days list. Both data will be reported on the school level, differentiate between students and staff, and will be suppressed to prevent potential identification of individuals who have the disease. Additionally, only those individuals who physically attend school (for instruction and/or extracurricular activities) on a regular basis will be included in the counts. This information will be provided for both public and private K-12 schools.

post_text: The Marion County School District has had an overwhelming response for the Marion Virtual Academy (MVA). Many Families have chosen to attend the MVA and committed to a full year of learning using this model, while others have opted to stay in the traditional setting which will open with remote learning in place until DHEC statistics indicate a decrease in risk for our county. Families that want to transfer at the semester break in January will be considered if room is available in the traditional model but, there is no guarantee. For staffing and scheduling purposes decisions will be final as of Thursday, August 13, 2020, at noon. After this deadline, the district will not allow transitioning between the two models.

The Carolina Collaborative for Alternative Certification is part of a unique program developed by the University of South Carolina in partnership with the Center for Teaching Quality and partnering school districts. CarolinaCAP is a non-degree program leading to full South Carolina licensure as a teacher.

Join us on Wednesday, April 8th from 2pm – 3pm for the CarolinaCAP recruitment webinar. During this informative session, participants will learn more about:
program partners,
program design,
admission requirements,

program costs.

A Message From Your School Counselor

Events like the recent outbreak of the Coronavirus can confuse, worry, and stress children to a degree that causes them far more harm than good. Young children should be spared details about infection rates and death tolls, which can needlessly terrify when they are ill equipped to process the information in the way that adults are able to. Please avoid the news and other types of social media to keep children calm.
I am available to talk with children and parents through telephone or e-mail to discuss these issues. Please feel free to e-mail me (lwillis@marion.k12.sc.us) or call me at (910)785-6485. I know that it is hard to maintain normalcy, but please continue to let children do their school work and have fun. Remember to keep them on a schedule as much as possible.

Thank you,
L. Willis
